HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 23, 1926.

A SLIPPING OPPORTUNITY
As usual, conditions at the Barn, especially the crowding
of the second floor at noon, are the subject of a great, deal of
unfavorable criticism. From the cramped little offices adjoining the main room, comments have been made concerning
the untidy group that, in the course of its collective lunch,
litters the floor with paper, and spills milk and coffee, which
form little pools on the floor. Doubtlessly some individuals
are to blame, but in the main it is not their fault. The real
trouble is that the Barn is too small and ill equipped to serve
as a center of student life.
For a long time there has been agitation for a real activities building, but now when a favorable opportunity seems to
have presented itself, the campus is regarding- the project with
the greatest indifference. When it.seemed that the plan would
be carried out at once and work on the building would be started
probably next tall, everyone voiced an unenthusiastic approval
and went about his business. By this time, when it seems That
the project will be postponed fo-r a somewhat indefinite period,
everybody has forgotten about it.
We cannot understand the indifferent attitude on the cainpus. For years an adequate students' building has been the
ideal of every man in any way connected with activities. Now,
when it seems within reach, everyone, including the chronic
objectors to the crowding at lunch time, and the limitations or
space which cramp the different activities,-has--forgotten about
it.
The University and the Y. M. C. A. can hardly be expected
to hurry in the construction of an activities building to which
the students are indifferent. The way in which the suggestion
that the students themselves raise money to furnish the building was received showed the apathy on the campus. The student activities council voted that any activity that wished to
was authorized to use its surplus in furnishing its own quarters
in the new building. The raising of money to furnish the rest
of the building was decided to lie out of the scope of the council, and it recommended that the work be carried out by some
other campus organizatio.n—the undergraduate Y. M. C. A.,
0. D. K.; or the Student Council. And here the matter has
rested. Nothing further has been done; not a ripple of interest
has been aroused.
Much regret has been expressed that activities will be
weakened, perhaps killed, by the new plan. Meanwhile, the
administration presents a plan for a building which', will
strengthen both activities and college life in general, and the
students are letting opportunities for support and co-operation
slip by.
We would like to see the drive supported, and supported
once. The actual money raised might be only a very small
.1I ion of the whole amount; but the attitude of the campus
the matter may play an important part when the status
ivi ties is determined in the future.

INCORPORATED

Hopkins will ha re a chance to
revenge this defeat, however, on
Hay 8th, when Maryland is met
in. a dual Meet at Homewood
*
*
*
Navy seems to be having a difficult time with their spring athletics, this year. The track team,
in the two meets so far staged has
been beaten by both Maryland and
the University of Virginia. Both
of these meets were very closely
contested. The baseball team so
far has had a most disastrous
season. William and Mary and
Vermont are the only teams that
have been beaten, while Fordham
and several other colleges have
rolled up trenmendous 'scores
against them. The lacrosse team,
however, demonstrated last Saturday by defeating Lafayette, 23-0,
that it 'is not, what early season
dope stated, a weak team. The
tennis team having lost to Columbia and beaten Hopkins does not
seem to be exceptionally strong.

a vy is trying out a new plan
in lacrosse by having two captains: a defense captain and an
attack captain. Each guides the
play in his respective end of the
field. Judging from the score of
the game Saturday it must work
out successfully.
Two of Army's players in tomorrow's game were stars last
fall on the gridiron. These men,
Baxter and Wilson, have been
playing a bang-up game this
spring are expected to give the
Hopkins team much trouble. Last
spring, Wilson was instrumental
in the West Pointers' victory over
Navy. Besides being a member of
the lacrosse and football teams,
he is also an excellent guard on
the basketball team.

omitted.

be taken as an indorsement of its views
by the "News-Letter," which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 23, 1926.

A SLIPPING OPPORTUNITY
As usual, conditions at the Barn, especially the crowding
of the second floor at noon, are the subject of a great, deal of
unfavorable criticism. From the cramped little offices adjoining the main room, comments have been made concerning
the untidy group that, in the course of its collective lunch,
litters the floor with paper, and spills milk and coffee, which
form little pools on the floor. Doubtlessly some individuals
are to blame, but in the main it is not their fault. The real
trouble is that the Barn is too small and ill equipped to serve
as a center of student life.
For a long time there has been agitation for a real activities building, but now when a favorable opportunity seems to
have presented itself, the campus is regarding- the project with
the greatest indifference. When it.seemed that the plan would
be carried out at once and work on the building would be started
probably next tall, everyone voiced an unenthusiastic approval
and went about his business. By this time, when it seems That
the project will be postponed fo-r a somewhat indefinite period,
everybody has forgotten about it.
We cannot understand the indifferent attitude on the cainpus. For years an adequate students' building has been the
ideal of every man in any way connected with activities. Now,
when it seems within reach, everyone, including the chronic
objectors to the crowding at lunch time, and the limitations or
space which cramp the different activities,-has--forgotten about
it.
The University and the Y. M. C. A. can hardly be expected
to hurry in the construction of an activities building to which
the students are indifferent. The way in which the suggestion
that the students themselves raise money to furnish the building was received showed the apathy on the campus. The student activities council voted that any activity that wished to
was authorized to use its surplus in furnishing its own quarters
in the new building. The raising of money to furnish the rest
of the building was decided to lie out of the scope of the council, and it recommended that the work be carried out by some
other campus organizatio.n—the undergraduate Y. M. C. A.,
0. D. K.; or the Student Council. And here the matter has
rested. Nothing further has been done; not a ripple of interest
has been aroused.
Much regret has been expressed that activities will be
weakened, perhaps killed, by the new plan. Meanwhile, the
administration presents a plan for a building which', will
strengthen both activities and college life in general, and the
students are letting opportunities for support and co-operation
slip by.
We would like to see the drive supported, and supported
once. The actual money raised might be only a very small
.1I ion of the whole amount; but the attitude of the campus
the matter may play an important part when the status
ivi ties is determined in the future.

INCORPORATED

Hopkins will ha re a chance to
revenge this defeat, however, on
Hay 8th, when Maryland is met
in. a dual Meet at Homewood
*
*
*
Navy seems to be having a difficult time with their spring athletics, this year. The track team,
in the two meets so far staged has
been beaten by both Maryland and
the University of Virginia. Both
of these meets were very closely
contested. The baseball team so
far has had a most disastrous
season. William and Mary and
Vermont are the only teams that
have been beaten, while Fordham
and several other colleges have
rolled up trenmendous 'scores
against them. The lacrosse team,
however, demonstrated last Saturday by defeating Lafayette, 23-0,
that it 'is not, what early season
dope stated, a weak team. The
tennis team having lost to Columbia and beaten Hopkins does not
seem to be exceptionally strong.

consumed by flames and replaced

1, 1907, when was held, pompous
and resplendent, the second cotilliOn of the year. It was rather
the occasion of Baltimore's first
taste of the stupendous truth—
that skirts would rise with prices.

athletic banners and floral dec.
orations, and Professor Emrich's
orchestra was stationed behind a
mass of palms on the stage. Between the halves, each of which
consisted of a series of eight
dances, supper was served in the
Donovan room, which is soon to
be the seat of the new Hopkins
Art Gallery.
